title: Quiz - Economic History of India - Part 1

quiz.text: Which of the following points is the rationale behind the introduction of mixed economy in India? ​
options: To control the distribution of essential commodities
To direct investment in socially desirable channels
To protect the weaker sections
To promote infrastructural facilities like hydro-electric projects, irrigation; road and railway transport
All of the above

quiz.text: Given below are some of the features of economic planning in Country X. 1. State fully controls the economic affairs, productive resources and economic decisions 2. State is the final authority in allocating the productive resources 3. The profits or production instead of being pocketed by the private capitalists go to the state for ameliorating the problems of the poor lots in the country Which type of economic planning has the features mentioned above?
options: Totalitarian
Democratic
Decentralized
Functional
None of the above

quiz.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Functional Planning?
options: Under functional planning, there is no need to build up new structure, rather the existing structure is corrected and modified
According to Zweig in his “The Planning of Free Societies’ has stated “Functional planning will only repair, not build a new, it will improve the wave of the existing order, but not supersede it.
It is a conservative, or rather evolutionary type of planning which will not over turn the existing structure and moves only within its narrow border
Functional planning brings drastic change in the economic and social set up of the country.
None of the  above

quiz.text: Which of the following is incorrect with respect to Perspective Planning?
options: It is a long run planning where targets are fixed for long periods, for example 15 to 25 years
A perspective plan means one plan for the complete period
The perspective plan has so many administrative difficulties due to which the fulfilment of the objectives becomes difficult
The long-run objectives are divided into short- run so that one by one all the objectives are achieved in the long-run
None of the above

quiz.text: Who was the chairman of the Economic Programme Committee (EPC) that was formed by All India Congress Committee in 1947?
options: Sardar Vallabh Bhai Patel
Jawahar Lal Nehru
Rajendra Prasad
BR Ambedkar
S.C. Bose

quiz.text: Which of the following is/are long term objectives of our five-year plans? 1. A high rate of growth to improve the standard of living of residents. 2. Economic self-reliance. 3. Social justice and reduction of inequalities. 4. Modernization of the economy.
options: 1,2 & 3 only
2,3 & 4 only
1,3 & 4 only
1,2,3 & 4
1 and 2 Only

quiz.text: Which five-year plan was launched in 1992 after the initiation of structural adjustment policies in the Indian economy?
options: Fifth
Sixth
Seventh
Eighth
Tenth

quiz.text: On which date did the India’s last five-year plan i.e. 12th five-year plan come to an end?
options: 31st March, 2017
31st December, 2017
31st March, 2018
31st December, 2018
31st March, 2019

quiz.text: Which of the following is not one of the feature of Indicative Planning?
options: Indicative plan is not imperative but flexible
It is peculiar to the mixed economy of France
The private sector is rigidly controlled to achieve the targets and priorities of the plan
All are features of indicative planning
Both A and B

quiz.text: Which of the following is/are features of imperative planning? 1. It refers to an economy where all economic activities and resources of the country operate under the direction of the state. 2. Consumer’s sovereignty is of utmost priority under this type of planning. 3. The government policies are rigid which cannot be changed easily
options: 1 and 2 only
1 and  3 only
2 and 3 only
1,2 and 3
2 only

quiz.text: Which of the following is not a feature of fixed planning?
options: Fixed planning is for some fixed period, say four or five or six or seven years
A fixed plan fixes definite objectives which have to be achieved during the plan period
A major disadvantage of this plan is constant lingering uncertainty associated with this plan
This plan helps in maintaining proper balance in the economy
None of the above

quiz.text: Which of the following is/are the features of People’s Plan put forth by MN Roy? 1. This plan was for ten years period 2. The plan gave greatest priority to Industrial Development 3. Nationalization of agriculture and production was the main feature of this plan 4. This plan was based on Marxist socialism
options: 1,2 and 3 only
2,3 and 4 only
1,3 and 4 only
1,2 and 4 only
1 and 3 only

quiz.text: Which of the following is/are incorrect with respect to five-year plans in India?
options: The first Five-year Plan was launched in 1949.
Three annual Plans were launched between 1966 and 1969.

For the first eight Plans the emphasis was on a growing public sector with massive investments in basic and heavy industries, but since the launch of the Ninth Plan in 1997, the emphasis on the public sector has become less pronounced.
The Eighth Plan could not take off in 1990 due to the fast changing political situation at the Centre and the years 1990-91 and 1991-92 were treated as Annual Plans.
None of the above

quiz.text: Given below are the features of one of the five-year plans of India: 1. Nehru-Mahalanobis model was adopted. 2. Overall objective was ‘Rapid industrialization with particular emphasis on the development of basic and heavy industries’ Identify the five year plan from above lines?
options: First
Second
Third
Fourth
Sixth

quiz.text: NABARD was established during which five-year plan?
options: Third
Fourth
Fifth
Sixth
Tenth

quiz.text:
Economic Planning is the making of major economic decisions. What and how is to be produced and to whom it is to be allocated – by the conscious decision of a determinate authority, on the basis of a comprehensive survey of the economic system as a whole. In an economy like India, the basis socioeconomic problems like poverty, unemployment, stagnation in agricultural and industrial production and inequality in the distribution of income and wealth can hardly be solved within the framework of an unplanned economy planning is required to remove these basic maladies. Economic Planning can be of different types like Centralized-Decentralized, Indicative-Imperative etc.

Which of the following points to importance of Economic Planning in India?

1. Increase in National Income

2. Equal distribution of wealth

3. Elimination of regional disparity

4. Improvement in Balance of Payment

5. Decrease in Capital Formation
options: 1, 2, 3 and 5 only
1, 2, 3 and 4 only
1, 2 and 3 only
2 and 3 only
1 and 4 only

quiz.text: ​Economic Planning is the making of major economic decisions. What and how is to be produced and to whom it is to be allocated – by the conscious decision of a determinate authority, on the basis of a comprehensive survey of the economic system as a whole. In an economy like India, the basis socioeconomic problems like poverty, unemployment, stagnation in agricultural and industrial production and inequality in the distribution of income and wealth can hardly be solved within the framework of an unplanned economy planning is required to remove these basic maladies. Economic Planning can be of different types like Centralized-Decentralized, Indicative-Imperative etc.​ Which of the following types of Economic Planning is being described in the following lines: It implies a system of economic order in which the authority that vests in the state is based on the support of common masses. In this type of planning, the state does not control all the means of production and does not regulate economic operations of the private economy directly.
options: Democratic
Totalitarian
Functional
Centralized
None of the options given above

quiz.text:
​Economic Planning is the making of major economic decisions. What and how is to be produced and to whom it is to be allocated – by the conscious decision of a determinate authority, on the basis of a comprehensive survey of the economic system as a whole. In an economy like India, the basis of socioeconomic problems like poverty, unemployment, stagnation in agricultural and industrial production and inequality in the distribution of income and wealth can hardly be solved within the framework of an unplanned economy planning is required to remove these basic maladies. Economic Planning can be of different types like Centralized-Decentralized, Indicative-Imperative, etc.​

Which of the following is/are correct regarding the difference between the Centralized and Decentralized forms of Planning?

  1. Decentralized planning is superior to centralized planning
  2. In centralized planning, framing, adopting, executing, supervising, and controlling the plan is done by the central planning authority while in decentralized planning, the responsibility lies with local and regional officials who take economic decisions about the plan.
  3. Centralized Planning is flexible and involves complete freedom, while there is a lack of complete freedom in decentralized Planning.
options: 1 only
1 and 2 only
2 and 3 only
2 only
1 and 3 only

quiz.text: ​​Economic Planning is the making of major economic decisions. What and how is to be produced and to whom it is to be allocated – by the conscious decision of a determinate authority, on the basis of a comprehensive survey of the economic system as a whole. In an economy like India, the basis socioeconomic problems like poverty, unemployment, stagnation in agricultural and industrial production and inequality in the distribution of income and wealth can hardly be solved within the framework of an unplanned economy planning is required to remove these basic maladies. Economic Planning can be of different types like Centralized-Decentralized, Indicative-Imperative etc.​​ Which of the following is incorrect regarding structural planning?​
options: In this type of planning the present social and economic structure is changed and a new structure emerges.
In the developed countries, there is a structural planning
Shift from capitalist to socialist economy can be called a structural change
Structural planning can help in accelerating the pace of economic development
None of the options given above

quiz.text:
​​​Economic Planning is the making of major economic decisions. What and how is to be produced and to whom it is to be allocated – by the conscious decision of a determinate authority, on the basis of a comprehensive survey of the economic system as a whole. In an economy like India, the basis socioeconomic problems like poverty, unemployment, stagnation in agricultural and industrial production and inequality in the distribution of income and wealth can hardly be solved within the framework of an unplanned economy planning is required to remove these basic maladies. Economic Planning can be of different types like Centralized-Decentralized, Indicative-Imperative etc.​​​

Which of the following is/are correct about Annual Planning or Prospective Planning?

1. Annual Planning or short-term planning refers to 4 to 6 years plans which are further divided into annual plans.

2. Plans are further divided into regional and sectional plans.

3. Regional plans are linked with regions, district and localities which are further divided into sectional plans for agriculture, industry, transport, foreign trade etc.
options: 1 & 2 only
2 & 3 only
1 & 3 only
1, 2 and 3
1 only

quiz.text:
A decade ago, India was a rising star in the global economy, with its annual growth rate touching 8-9% between 2003 and 2008, with price stability and modest fiscal and balance of payments deficits. It was hailed as one of the fastest-growing large economies, nipping at China’s heels and reckoned as the emerging global back office as against China being the world’s factory. That boom is associated with a sharp upturn in the investment rate peaking at 38% of GDP in 2007-08, with rising domestic saving financing (most) of this investment. Unprecedented foreign capital inflows – foreign direct investment (FDI), foreign portfolio investment (FPI) and external commercial borrowings (ECBs) – at close to 10% of GDP supplemented domestic resources. A rising share of short-term financial inflows caused concerns about financial fragility. The Global Financial Crisis in 2008 upended the boom, though it affected India only modestly for two reasons: (i) its stricter financial regulations and (ii) relatively large and closed domestic markets. After a brief dip in 2008-09, India, thanks to accommodative monetary and looser fiscal policies (a concerted effort by the Group of 20 countries), witnessed a V-shaped recovery that lasted until 2011-12. Quantitative easing (QE) by advanced economies meant renewed capital inflows into emerging markets in search of better yields (that is, higher returns), until the wake-up call of the ‘Taper Tantrum’ (in May 2013) – when the US Federal Reserve hinted at raising interest rates – took place, reminding India of the perils of fickle capital inflows.

In the context of the above passage, which of the following best describes the meaning of Accommodative Monetary Policy?
options: When a central bank attempts to expand the overall money supply when growth is slowing.
When a central bank attempts to contract the overall money supply when growth is rising.
When a central bank attempts to maintain neutral stance in overall money supply.
When a central bank attempts to expand the overall money supply when economy is rising.
When a central bank attempts to contract the overall money supply when growth is slowing.

quiz.text:
A decade ago, India was a rising star in the global economy, with its annual growth rate touching 8-9% between 2003 and 2008, with price stability and modest fiscal and balance of payments deficits. It was hailed as one of the fastest-growing large economies, nipping at China’s heels and reckoned as the emerging global back office as against China being the world’s factory. That boom is associated with a sharp upturn in the investment rate peaking at 38% of GDP in 2007-08, with rising domestic saving financing (most) of this investment. Unprecedented foreign capital inflows – foreign direct investment (FDI), foreign portfolio investment (FPI) and external commercial borrowings (ECBs) – at close to 10% of GDP supplemented domestic resources. A rising share of short-term financial inflows caused concerns about financial fragility. The Global Financial Crisis in 2008 upended the boom, though it affected India only modestly for two reasons: (i) its stricter financial regulations and (ii) relatively large and closed domestic markets. After a brief dip in 2008-09, India, thanks to accommodative monetary and looser fiscal policies (a concerted effort by the Group of 20 countries), witnessed a V-shaped recovery that lasted until 2011-12. Quantitative easing (QE) by advanced economies meant renewed capital inflows into emerging markets in search of better yields (that is, higher returns), until the wake-up call of the ‘Taper Tantrum’ (in May 2013) – when the US Federal Reserve hinted at raising interest rates – took place, reminding India of the perils of fickle capital inflows.

In the context of the above passage, consider the following statements:

1) Because of the speed of economic adjustment and recovery in macroeconomic performance, a V-shaped recovery is a best case scenario given the recession.

2) In V shape recovery jobs are permanently lost.

3) A V-shaped recovery is characterized by a slow and gradual recovery in measures of economic performance after a sharp economic decline

Which of the statements given above is/are not correct?
options: 1 only
2 only
2 and 3 only
3 only
1,2 and 3

quiz.text:
A decade ago, India was a rising star in the global economy, with its annual growth rate touching 8-9% between 2003 and 2008, with price stability and modest fiscal and balance of payments deficits. It was hailed as one of the fastest-growing large economies, nipping at China’s heels and reckoned as the emerging global back office as against China being the world’s factory. That boom is associated with a sharp upturn in the investment rate peaking at 38% of GDP in 2007-08, with rising domestic saving financing (most) of this investment. Unprecedented foreign capital inflows – foreign direct investment (FDI), foreign portfolio investment (FPI) and external commercial borrowings (ECBs) – at close to 10% of GDP supplemented domestic resources. A rising share of short-term financial inflows caused concerns about financial fragility. The Global Financial Crisis in 2008 upended the boom, though it affected India only modestly for two reasons: (i) its stricter financial regulations and (ii) relatively large and closed domestic markets. After a brief dip in 2008-09, India, thanks to accommodative monetary and looser fiscal policies (a concerted effort by the Group of 20 countries), witnessed a V-shaped recovery that lasted until 2011-12. Quantitative easing (QE) by advanced economies meant renewed capital inflows into emerging markets in search of better yields (that is, higher returns), until the wake-up call of the ‘Taper Tantrum’ (in May 2013) – when the US Federal Reserve hinted at raising interest rates – took place, reminding India of the perils of fickle capital inflows.

In the context of the above passage, consider the following statements with respect to Quantitative Easing:

1) It is a form of fiscal policy used by the government as a method of quickly increasing the domestic money supply and spurring economic activity.

2) It includes purchasing of longer-term government bonds, as well as other types of assets, such as mortgage-backed securities (MBS).

3) It is conducted every month.

Which of the statements given above is/are not correct?
options: 1 only
2 only
2 and 3 only
3 only
1 and 3 only

quiz.text:
A decade ago, India was a rising star in the global economy, with its annual growth rate touching 8-9% between 2003 and 2008, with price stability and modest fiscal and balance of payments deficits. It was hailed as one of the fastest-growing large economies, nipping at China’s heels and reckoned as the emerging global back office as against China being the world’s factory. That boom is associated with a sharp upturn in the investment rate peaking at 38% of GDP in 2007-08, with rising domestic saving financing (most) of this investment. Unprecedented foreign capital inflows – foreign direct investment (FDI), foreign portfolio investment (FPI) and external commercial borrowings (ECBs) – at close to 10% of GDP supplemented domestic resources. A rising share of short-term financial inflows caused concerns about financial fragility. The Global Financial Crisis in 2008 upended the boom, though it affected India only modestly for two reasons: (i) its stricter financial regulations and (ii) relatively large and closed domestic markets. After a brief dip in 2008-09, India, thanks to accommodative monetary and looser fiscal policies (a concerted effort by the Group of 20 countries), witnessed a V-shaped recovery that lasted until 2011-12. Quantitative easing (QE) by advanced economies meant renewed capital inflows into emerging markets in search of better yields (that is, higher returns), until the wake-up call of the ‘Taper Tantrum’ (in May 2013) – when the US Federal Reserve hinted at raising interest rates – took place, reminding India of the perils of fickle capital inflows.

In the context of the above passage, consider the following statements:

1) Annual growth rate of India has been continuously rising since Global Financial Crisis of 2007-08.

2) Share of agriculture sector has been rising continuously since 1991 reforms.

3) Service sector contributes more than half in India’s GDP.

Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
options: 1 only
2 only
2 and 3 only
3 only
All of the above

quiz.text:
India’s transformative economic reforms were introduced a quarter-century ago, in 1991. When India sought International Monetary Fund (IMF) assistance to deal with the crisis, that assistance came with reform conditions attached, as is usual for Fund programmes. This led to the belief that the liberalization reforms were imposed by the IMF and other multilateral institutions. Certainly, in the absence of the crisis, the rush to reform may not have played out the way it did, supported by an IMF adjustment programme. The main components of reform were already on the table well before the 1991 crisis. Some partial reforms were even initiated during the 1980s, which saw a spurt in growth. But the reforms were then politically derailed, and it was only under P.V. Narasimha Rao that the full package of stabilization plus structural reforms was put back on the rails in 1991. Some of these reforms were implemented immediately following their announcement in the 1991 budget. Others were implemented during the next one or two years. Yet other reforms were stretched over several years.

 

In the context of the above passage, consider the following statements:

1) Economic reforms denote the process in which a government prescribes declining role for state and expanding role for the private sector in an economy.

2) It is safer to see economic reform as a policy shift in an economy from one to another or alternative development strategy.

3) India carried huge structural economic reforms immediately after the independence.

Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
options: 1 only
1 and 2 only
2 and 3 only
3 only
All of the above

quiz.text:
India’s transformative economic reforms were introduced a quarter-century ago, in 1991. When India sought International Monetary Fund (IMF) assistance to deal with the crisis, that assistance came with reform conditions attached, as is usual for Fund programmes. This led to the belief that the liberalization reforms were imposed by the IMF and other multilateral institutions. Certainly, in the absence of the crisis, the rush to reform may not have played out the way it did, supported by an IMF adjustment programme. The main components of reform were already on the table well before the 1991 crisis. Some partial reforms were even initiated during the 1980s, which saw a spurt in growth. But the reforms were then politically derailed, and it was only under P.V. Narasimha Rao that the full package of stabilization plus structural reforms was put back on the rails in 1991. Some of these reforms were implemented immediately following their announcement in the 1991 budget. Others were implemented during the next one or two years. Yet other reforms were stretched over several years.

 In the context of the above passage, consider the following statements with respect to economic liberalization:

1) Licensing system has been removed for all the industries.

2) Foreign banks were allowed to open their branch in India subject to regulations.

3) Rate of corporation tax has been raised as foreign companies were allowed to set their branch in India.

Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
options: 1 only
1 and 2 only
2 and 3 only
3 only
2 only

quiz.text:
India’s transformative economic reforms were introduced a quarter-century ago, in 1991. When India sought International Monetary Fund (IMF) assistance to deal with the crisis, that assistance came with reform conditions attached, as is usual for Fund programmes. This led to the belief that the liberalization reforms were imposed by the IMF and other multilateral institutions. Certainly, in the absence of the crisis, the rush to reform may not have played out the way it did, supported by an IMF adjustment programme. The main components of reform were already on the table well before the 1991 crisis. Some partial reforms were even initiated during the 1980s, which saw a spurt in growth. But the reforms were then politically derailed, and it was only under P.V. Narasimha Rao that the full package of stabilization plus structural reforms was put back on the rails in 1991. Some of these reforms were implemented immediately following their announcement in the 1991 budget. Others were implemented during the next one or two years. Yet other reforms were stretched over several years. 

 In the context of the above passage, consider the following statements regarding the Structural Reform Measures adopted by Indian during the Economic reforms of 1991:

  1. Structural Reform Measures include all the policy reforms which have been initiated by the government to boost the aggregate supply of goods and services in the economy.
  2. It naturally entails unshackling the economy so that it may search for its own potential of enhanced productivity and production.
  3. Under this measure, for the purchasing capacity of the people to be decreased, the economy needs increased income which comes from increased levels of activities.

Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
options: 1 only
1 and 2 only
2 and 3 only
3 only
All of the above

quiz.text:
India’s transformative economic reforms were introduced a quarter-century ago, in 1991. When India sought International Monetary Fund (IMF) assistance to deal with the crisis, that assistance came with reform conditions attached, as is usual for Fund programmes. This led to the belief that the liberalization reforms were imposed by the IMF and other multilateral institutions. Certainly, in the absence of the crisis, the rush to reform may not have played out the way it did, supported by an IMF adjustment programme. The main components of reform were already on the table well before the 1991 crisis. Some partial reforms were even initiated during the 1980s, which saw a spurt in growth. But the reforms were then politically derailed, and it was only under P.V. Narasimha Rao that the full package of stabilization plus structural reforms was put back on the rails in 1991. Some of these reforms were implemented immediately following their announcement in the 1991 budget. Others were implemented during the next one or two years. Yet other reforms were stretched over several years.

 In the context of the above passage, consider the following statements regarding the Economic reforms in India:

1) In July 1991, India launched a process of economic reforms in response to a fiscal and Balance of Payment crisis.

2) The reforms of the 1990s witnessed rather limited nature of deregulation and ‘partial liberalisation of only a few aspects of the existing control regime.

3) The reforms started in early 1980s in the fields of industries, trade, investment and later to include agriculture, were much ‘wider and deeper’.

Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
options: 1 only
1 and 2 only
2 and 3 only
3 only
All of the above

quiz.text:
Consider the following statements regarding the term ‘privatization’, one of the facets of economic reforms in India:

1) Privatisation in its purest sense and lexically means de-nationalization i.e., transfer of the state ownership of the assets to the private sector.

2) Management control is never transferred by the government in case of selling of shares to private sector.

3) Disinvestment is a part of privatisation process.

Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
options: 1 only
1 and 2 only
1 and 3 only
3 only
All of the above

quiz.text: Special Drawing Rights (SDRs), an international reserve asset, was created by which of the following organisation?
options: World Bank
World Trade Organization (WTO)
International Monetary Fund (IMF)
Asian Development Bank
None of the Above

quiz.text:
____________ implies a system of economic order in which the authority that vests in the state is based on the support of common masses. In ___________, the state does not control all the means of production and does not regulate economic operations of the private economy directly. In ___________, the plan is fully debated in the Parliament, state legislature and in the private forums.

Which of the following should be filled in the space given above?
options: Democratic Planning
Totalitarian Planning
Centralized Planning
Decentralized Planning
Functional Planning

quiz.text:
Which of the following are correct regarding growth during the reform period?
  1.  The growth of agriculture declined.
  2. The service sector reported fluctuation.
  3. The growth of industrial sectors has gone up.
  4. The growth during this phase was mainly driven by the growth in the service sector.
Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
options: 1,2 and 3 only
2 and 4 only
1 and 4 only
1 and 3 only
All of the above

quiz.text:
Consider the following statements regarding the impact of economic reforms on agriculture:

1) Public investment in agriculture sector has increased only slightly, in the reform period.

2) The removal of fertiliser subsidy has led to increase in the cost of production, which has severely affected the small and marginal farmers.

3) The focus has mostly been on the production of food grains for the domestic market.

Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
options: 1 and 3 only
2 only
1 and 2 only
1 and 3 only
All of the above

quiz.text:
Consider the following statements regarding reasons for slowdown in Industrial growth during the period of economic reforms:

1) Decreasing demand of domestic industrial products.

2) Globalization.

3) India still does not have the access to developed countries’ markets because of high non-tariff barriers.

4) Low imports of industrial goods from foreign countries.

Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
options: 1 and 3 only
2 only
1 and 4 only
1, 2 and 3 only
All of the above

quiz.text: Consider the following statements regarding the NITI Aayog: 1) NITI Aayog was formed on 25 January 2016. 2) NITI Aayog is chaired by the President of India. 3) The full form of NITI Aayog is National Institution for Transforming India. 4) The NITI Aayog is a policy think tank of the Government of India. Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
options: 1 and 3 only
4 only
3  and 4 only
1, 2 and 3 only
All of the above
